headline.main: The E.P.A.'s tough standards: cost isn't a consideration.

docs.abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene article on Environmental Protection Agency plan to tighten air quality standards for ozone and particles in dust and soot; cites concern EPA uses strong case for curbing particulates to mask relatively weak case against ozone; questions whether high cost of meeting new ozone standards is justified; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER years of hinting, the Environmental Protection Agency now wants to tighten air quality standards for ozone and the tiny particles in dust and soot. That's good, right? After all, the new rules are designed to meet the letter and spirit of the Clean Air Act, which requires the agency to ''protect public health with an ample margin of safety.'' But they are raising eyebrows among economists inclined to look much more critically at the costs of regulation as well as the benefits.

headline.main: Teaching Youths the Risks of Smoking

docs.abstract: Excerpts from interview with Joel Gurin, editorial director of Consumers Union, on his efforts to teach youths about risks of smoking; Consumers Union, in collaboration with HBO, has produced special half-hour television program aimed at children 10 through 14 to acquaint them with risks of smoking and advise them as to how to avoid starting and how to stop if they have already started; photo (L)

keywords.value: SMOKE ALARM: THE UNFILTERED TRUTH ABOUT CIGARETTES (TV PROGRAM)
keywords.name: creative_works

docs.lead_paragraph: JOEL GURIN of Scarsdale, the editorial director of Consumers Union, never smoked, he said, perhaps because his mother died of lung cancer when he was a teen-ager. Mr. Gurin said he is one of the lucky ones who was able to resist the daily assault of the tobacco industry as it spends $6 billion a year -- $700,000 every every hour of every day of every year -- to promote its products to young people. About 3,000 children under 18 start smoking each day, he said, and a third of them will die prematurely.

headline.kicker: Our Cures for the Drug Problem Make It Worse

docs.abstract: Thomas G Steffens letter says progress will not be made against drug abuse until the issue is purged of its moral baggage
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Nov. 19 letters debating the drug problem have one thing in common with all polemics on drugs: they talk past one another. Rather than discuss ways of solving ''the'' problem, they discuss two different problems. As a moral issue, the problem is the fight against evil. As a practical issue, the problem is adverse side effects. Side effects, medical or social, are tangible entities that can be dealt with by rational means. In this context, the drug problem will be transformed into a problem no different from cigarette smoking or alcoholism. We won't make progress until we rid the issue of its emotional moral baggage. THOMAS G. STEFFENS Jamaica Estates, Queens, Nov. 20, 1996 The writer is a professor of pharmacology at SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn.
